title: Challenger banks ramp up lending as demand soars
text:

Thu, Oct 15, 2015, 14:15 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 15 mins Challenger banks ramp up lending as demand soars By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 26 minutes ago 0.000 
Lending volumes rocketed at both Virgin Money and Secure Trust Bank over the past year 
Challenger (Hamburg: 4SE.HM - news ) banks Virgin Money and Secure Trust Bank are increasing the pressure on their big high street rivals, with their lending volumes rising rapidly this year as consumers shop around for better deals on their loans and deposits. 
Virgin Money lent out £5.5bn in mortgages in the first nine months of the year, up 38pc on the same period of 2014. 
Once repayments are included, net lending almost doubled, rising 98pc to £2.6bn in the first three quarters of 2015. That means the bank has a market share of 3.5pc so far this year, up from 3.1pc in the second half of 2014. 
Outstanding mortgage balances hit £24.5bn in the quarter, up 12pc on their level at the start of the year. However, the bank did warn that increased competition as yet more challenger banks enter the market is keeping mortgage interest rates low, putting pressure on profitability . 
Virgin Money is also expanding its credit card business, and outstanding balances on the plastic now stand at £1.4bn. The challenger bank wants to increase that to £3bn by the end of 2018. 
At the same time retail deposits increased 3pc in the quarter to £23.7bn. 
The challenger also hired George Ashworth from rival lender Aldermore , to launch its small- and medium-sized business banking operations. 
Virgin Money floated on the stock market in November 2014, and its share price has risen by 45pc in the 11 months since the initial public offering. 
Meanwhile, fellow challenger bank Secure Trust , which is part of the Arbuthnot Banking (LSE: ARBB.L - news ) Group, also reported very strong lending figures. 
New (KOSDAQ: 160550.KQ - news ) lending volumes rose 93pc, taking Secure Trust’s loan book to above £900m, with growing volumes across consumer and motor finance arms, as well as its small business operations including asset finance, invoice finance and real estate finance. 
Secure Trust Bank has also poached a senior executive from a rival to bolster its operations. It has hired Ian Henderson , formerly chief executive at Kensington Mortgages and at Shawbrook Bank, to head up its strategy, personal lending and mortgage units   .
